EDUCATION POLICY


    Order read for resumption of adjourned debate on Question (17th January, 1962).

    "That this Assembly calls upon the Government to recommend the appointment of a Commission to enquire into the Government's Education Policy, its content and administration in all fields other than vocational and technical education, and to make recommendations." -[Mr David Marshall].

    Question again proposed.

2.33 p.m.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, before the adjournment last evening I was replying to the Member for Tanglin when he mentioned the subject of character building in schools. I heartily agree with him that education is just not book learning and the passing of examinations. There are other aspects of education which have to be met by teachers, and in this respect, extra curricula activities are of importance which the Ministry would like to encourage. That being so, the Ministry has been thinking for some time of including extra curricula activities into the school curriculum, because with our extremely large school population and the maximum use to which school buildings are being put - most schools are now on a two-session basis, and certain schools are on a three-session basis to accommodate the adults at

Column: 330

night - it would be very difficult for schools to have extra curricula activities outside their school hours; in other words, for pupils in the morning session to return in the afternoon for their normal extra curricula activities, and vice versa. Unfortunately, we are not in a position to implement this for this year since Government has decided to appoint this Commission of Inquiry to review the whole of the educational system, including the six-day week.

    The Member for Tanglin did stress that our schools should not be too examination-conscious. Whilst I agree with him in this respect, I must also state the firm view of the Government that it does not favour the automatic promotion system which unfortunately existed in the English stream for quite a number of years and has had serious effects not only on pupils but also on teachers. With the stoppage of automatic promotion for the English stream in 1959, there has been a distinct improvement in the quality of work not only from the pupils but also from the teachers. This is reflected in the improvement in the percentage of passes for the Primary School Leaving Examination for the last two years.

    I now wish to deal with the remarks made by my former Parliamentary Secretary, the Member for Serangoon Gardens, who is not in the House at the present moment. But he has said his piece, I presume, on behalf of the Barisan Sosialis which he represents today. I must say I am very grateful to the Member for Anson for moving this motion instead of withdrawing it, although he said last month he would, to give me this opportunity first to listen to my former Parliamentary Secretary who says certain things about the education policy, and for me to reply.

    He has stated that he fully supports the Commission of Inquiry that is to be formed to inquire into the educational policy of the Government. But he does not agree that a Commission of Inquiry should investigate into political activities in schools. I would like to remind the Member for Serangoon Gardens that there are two Commissions of Inquiry. The first one would be to

Column: 331

investigate into the examination boycott which would also include an investigation into the political activities and machinations in primary and secondary schools. This Commission will be headed by a High Court Judge, because we feel that it is most essential that politics should be got rid of in our school system. In fact, my former Parliamentary Secretary must have had a mental black-out (after he changed sides from the Government bench and walked across to be part of the Barisan Sosialis) to hear that under the Education Ordinance, 1957, there are published the School Regulations, 1957. At page 18 of the Regulations, Part XVIII, is a section which deals with political propaganda in schools. The marginal heading reads as follows: "No political teaching or activity detrimental to the State of Singapore." Regulation 110 reads as follows - I shall only read paragraph 110; there are two sections. The first section:

    `No instruction, education, entertainment, recreation, propaganda or activity of any kind which shall be in any way of a political or partly political nature or detrimental to the interests of the State of Singapore or of the pupils or contrary to the approved syllabus shall be permitted amongst the teachers or pupils either upon the school premises or elsewhere upon the occasion of any school activity or combined schools activity.'

Subsection (2) reads:

    `The use or display by teachers or pupils either upon the school premises or elsewhere upon the occasion of any school activity or combined schools activity or salutes, songs, dances, slogans, uniforms, flags or symbols which have a customarily political association shall be unlawful.'

    The Member for Serangoon Gardens stated that a Commission of Inquiry should look into the educational policy of the Government which he termed "has many defects in its policy". This is typical of the Barisan Sosialis type of allegation and accusation. They do not mean that. Why did the Member for Serangoon Gardens not state exactly what are the defects, and what do the Barisan Sosialis say should be done? In fact, Sir, it is the Member for Serangoon Gardens, formerly my Parliamentary Secretary, who dissociated himself from all the decisions taken by

Column: 332

him for the last two years until his removal as Parliamentary Secretary on 21st July, 1961. Was he not supposed to be my adviser on Chinese education, and that I sought his views first before I made any decision? So much so that I had to disappoint my loyal colleagues, the Member for Bras Basah and the Member for Tiong Bahru, when they had problems on Chinese education. I had to tell them first to discuss with the Parliamentary Secretary who is now the Member for Serangoon Gardens. They said they were so frustrated that it was no use talking to him; nothing was done. That was why they had to come to me. I should therefore like the Member for Serangoon Gardens to name the number of occasions when I rejected his recommendations when they were submitted to me, and for what reasons. I notice the Member for Upper Serangoon is all smiles, Sir, because he also acted as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education for at least one or two months when the Member for Serangoon Gardens went to New Zealand on a U.N.E.S.C.O. Seminar. When files continued to drift into the room of the Parliamentary Secretary, the Member for Upper Serangoon came to my room and said, "Stop sending all these files to me. Stop consulting me. You should just decide and carry on. I cannot stand the number of files that are coming to me. You are the Minister. Get on with the job." Such are the types of ex-colleagues we have. They wished to be consulted, and when we did consult them, they threw up their hands because there was too much work to do.

    So I do ask the Member for Serangoon Gardens, if he must criticise the educational policy of the Government, should he not try to confine his criticisms to the educational policy, if any, that appears to be wrong to him after he has been expelled from the P.A.P. Government? That is, from July 1961 until now. Or would he? The Member for Serangoon Gardens wants me to produce files upon files in the Ministry of Education to show his signature and his initial indicating his

Column: 333

decisions on matters of Chinese education, but he does not want to honour his own initial and his signature. One evening he stated that in the matter of the 4:2 system for Chinese secondary schools, if only Government had postponed the holding of the Secondary IV examination last year for one year, there would have been no trouble. Sir, I would like to ask who decided that the 1961 Secondary IV examination in Chinese schools should take place? I will not bore the House except to make references to certain files - Education File No. 1134/60, folio 36, - in which the minutes of the meeting of the Government Senior Middle III Examination Board, 1960, dated 18th November, 1960, were submitted to me on 23rd November. 1960. My minute to the Parliamentary Secretary, now the Member for Serangoon Gardens, was a short one: "O.K.?" I got a reply after one week. It takes a very long time for the Member for Serangoon Gardens to come to .any decision. In fact, Sir, after his removal, sad to say, documents, letters, appeals, which I passed down to him to attend and to "please deal with" were found stacked in the drawers, chockful, until my new Parliamentary Secretary turned up -

    Mr Ong Chang Sam (Choa Chu Kang): Ha, ha!

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr Lee Khoon Choy): What is there to laugh about?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: There were silver-fish and cockroaches inside the drawers and he wants this Commission of Inquiry!

    Mr Ong Chang Sam: Inquiry first.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Certainly. It took one week, Sir, on 30th November, for the Member for Serangoon Gardens to say, "O.K." to the minute. So the scope of the first Chinese Secondary school leaving examination (Secondary IV) was decided. A month later, 9th of December, he addressed a minute to me suggesting certain changes to the proposed examination of the Chinese Secondary school medium. On the same

Column: 334

day, I minuted, "Agree with the Parliamentary Secretary", and the decision went down. Therefore, Sir, if in 1960 it was decided to proceed with the first Government Secondary IV examination to be held in 1961, it was on the advice of my former Parliamentary Secretary, the Member for Serangoon Gardens.

    Sir, it would be very interesting to know that with this controversy between the 3:3 and 4:2 systems, at one stage the Chinese educational bodies were upset that schools could not issue their school certificates after an examination. Here again, Sir, who decided that the schools could not issue their school certificates in accordance with the usual practice? I refer to Education file 1299/61, folio (3) in which the Member for Serangoon Gardens, as my Parliamentary Secretary then, on the 5th July. 1961, gave approval to the issue of this circular which reads as follows. It was dated 11th July, 1961. The circular is numbered Education 1299/61/39:

    `Issue of certificates to pupils of Secondary IV classes.

    It was the practice of Chinese Middle Schools to issue their own Senior Middle III Certificates to pupils who completed their Senior Middle III. The Ministry has decided that this practice should not be extended to pupils who sit for the forthcoming School Certificate Chinese examination. Principals are, therefore, requested not to issue their own school certificates to such pupils.

    2. This ruling does not apply to the school leaving certificate issued by the school when a pupil leaves a school at any standard.'

Mind you, Sir, this decision was taken in spite of a warning by an official dated 4th July that it was expected that a section of the public would clamour for the retention of the traditional practice for schools to issue their own school certificates. That was my adviser on Chinese education! He took a decision and now he would like to make it appear that he was not consulted, nor does he know anything about it.

    I come now to the points which he considered the Commission of Inquiry should look into. They were five in number. The first one was this. Did Government assist aided schools to expand, since there were so few Chinese aided schools but so many English Government schools? The answer is

Column: 335

very simple, Sir. Assuming that we have done nothing, it can be asked, in whose hands did I leave the question of looking into the question of the granting of capital aid to schools, which are mainly Chinese? Whose recommendation was I waiting for, if it was not my former Parliamentary Secretary, the present Member for Serangoon Gardens, who sits on files like a hen squatting on eggs to hatch?

    Next, he referred to the retirement of teachers in aided schools whom he said Government has no plan to assist. He said that when they retire they would be jobless and unemployed. Sir, there is this distinction about teachers being employed in aided schools and teachers employed in Government service. Whereas a teacher wishing to be employed in an aided school could approach an individual school to see the Principal and get the approval of the Committee of Management prior to his appointment, particulars of which, of course, would have to be forwarded to the Ministry of Education for approval, in the case of employment in a Government school, there would be an open advertisement, and should there be a hundred vacancies, it is likely that at least 500 or 1,000 would apply for such vacancies. There would be strict selection by a Selection Board deputed by the Public Service Commission, and the best people would be selected for service. But the prize for being selected to Government service would mean that a teacher in Government service is liable for transfer anywhere within the State, whereas a teacher in an aided school remains more or less in that school for a long time. There are advantages and disadvantages, whether one happens to serve in an aided school or a Government school. It is not very easy to equate the terms and conditions of service. Whereas the Government servant would, after a long period of service, be entitled either to a part gratuity and pension; in the case of an aided school teacher, there would be his share of the Provident Fund; so either a teacher gets a Provident Fund or he is entitled to a pension. It is up to him to make up his mind what he

Column: 336

would like to have in his old age. He cannot possibly have both. If, therefore, teachers would like to look forward to a pension, they should then apply for a post in the Government service. There is, of course, this further advantage of serving in aided schools, as we have examples here, Sir. They are able to take part in politics and elections, get returned and become hon. Assemblymen; whereas a civil servant would not be entitled to take part in active politics. However, the Government is fully aware that Chinese aided schools did not get full aid till 1957. The Central Provident Fund, I think, came into existence only in 1957, that is, about two years before the new Government took office. Therefore, knowing full well that many Chinese teachers in aided schools would not have a proper nest egg for retirement, the Ministry took a very lenient view when the subject of the retirement of teachers came up for consideration. The normal retiring age is 55 and the Government has actually agreed that not only civil servants, but also teachers in aided schools could continue to serve up till 60, provided, of course, the teachers concerned are medically fit and also serve their purpose in schools; that they have a satisfactory record of teaching, and could be of service to the country; and even then, Sir, we were prepared to look into individual cases of Chinese teachers in aided schools who were over 60, if they felt that they could still carry on and were given permission to have their service extended year after year. I handed over to the Member for Serangoon Gardens, as my Parliamentary Secretary, the responsibility to look into individual cases, make recommendations and to allow for extensions. But I hear that there is an impression outside that many aged teachers who wished to continue in service were rather roughly treated by my ex-Parliamentary Secretary. I am afraid I cannot be responsible for his bad manners, but that was the impression I got after he stopped being my Parliamentary Secretary in July last year.

    He then touched upon the subject of the bleak future for students in our

Column: 337

schools and mentioned the fact that many Senior Middle III and Secondary IV graduates of Chinese secondary schools are unemployed. Sir, this is not typical of Chinese schools. The unfortunate thing about the Member for Serangoon Gardens is that he is only able to look from one angle. He is unable, despite the two years he was under my tutelage, to see education as a whole. We have four language streams. In his position, he should have been trained to look at education in more than one stream. Therefore, I would say that the problem of unemployment in the ranks of those who graduate from our secondary schools, be they Chinese or English, and in the near future from the Malay and Tamil streams, is a fact which this Government was fully aware of before it came into office. That is why we have tried to produce our development plan; it was originally meant to be five years, but because by the time it was published one year was already over, it became a Four-Year Plan - 1961 to 1964. We were fully aware of the unhealthy unemployment position which would be aggravated by the thousands that would be leaving our schools seeking employment. There is a need for industrialisation and a need for the conversion of the educational system which we have inherited from the past, in order to bring about greater emphasis and stress on vocational and technical education and not academic education as we have known for a long, long time. Therefore, before embarking on a large programme of very expensive vocational and technical education, we decided to set up a Commission of Inquiry into Vocational and Technical Education. This Commission's Report was tabled in this Assembly two months ago.

    The Member for Serangoon Gardens then went on to make a false statement that many Secondary IV students are not able to join Upper Secondary classes. Now, entry to the Upper Secondary classes in the Chinese medium which started this year is through passing the Secondary School IV Examination. Of 2,348 pupils who

Column: 338

passed the Secondary School IV Examination last year, 2,080 or 88 per cent - close to 90 per cent - have been admitted to Upper Secondary classes as at 13th of January this year.

    The Member next alleged that the Ministry has not recruited any temporary teachers pending the publishing of the results of the Senior Middle III Examination and the Secondary 1V Examination next month. This again is not true. We are employing and will employ those who have taken either the Senior Cambridge Examination, 1961, for the English stream and those who have taken the Government Senior Middle III Examination and the Government Secondary 1V Examination in the Chinese medium last month as temporary teachers for our schools. Of course, there has been a first recruitment of teachers as temporary teachers. There will be a second recruitment based on the fact that the first recruitment was on the basis that teacher trainees were regarded as one unit for purposes of staffing in the schools, and it has been decided that teacher trainees may have more free periods and could be regarded as .92 unit for 1962.

    The fourth point which the Member for Serangoon Gardens made and which he said should be put before the Commission of Inquiry was the question of the recognition of Nanyang University degrees. From the answer given by the Government to questions posed by the Chinese Chamber of Commerce at the forum debate at the Victoria Theatre on 13th January, he said he understood it to mean that the Government, after merger, would seek recognition of Nanyang University degrees, but that they should proceed to recognise this now. It would, I think, be fair if the full questions and answers were stated in the Assembly. It is very dangerous just picking out one line and then asking questions on that one line. It should be in the context of the question and answer. It is not very long, Sir. If you will allow me, this is question No. 15. The question posed was:

    "After merger, will the academic qualifications of Middle School graduates and University graduates, including those of Nanyang

Column: 339

University, be recognised by the Central Government of the new Federation; and will such graduates be allowed to teach or enter Government service in any part of the Federation?"

    The official text of the answer is as follows:

    "The question of academic qualifications of Middle School and University graduates, including those of Nanyang University, being recognised by the Central Government of the new Federation is a matter for the Central Government of the new Federation. Alter merger, the Singapore Government will put the merits of the case for recognition before the Central Government. However, after merger and with autonomy in education, Nanyang graduates will continue to be recruited for service in the Singapore Government and in schools. Since Singapore would enjoy autonomy in education after merger, the Singapore Government would naturally continue to recruit Nanyang University graduates into Government service, including the teaching service."

    I do not think it necessary to expand on that question and answer. Suffice it to say that the Singapore Government has given conditional recognition to Nanyang University degrees, a stand the Government took two years ago when the Gwee Ah Leng Review Committee Report on Nanyang University was tabled in this House, and I had then occasion to state the Singapore Government's stand on Nanyang University. I refer, Sir, to Hansard, Vol. 12, No. 3, col. 143. I will just read one and a half paragraphs:

    `From the Review Committee's Report, it appears that the curriculum of Nanyang University shows a lack of systematic planning and proper co-ordination, and individual guidance from staff members appears to be lacking.

    What then is the Singapore Government's stand on Nanyang University in view of the findings of the Gwee Ah Leng Review Committee? Despite the critical findings contained in the Review Committee's Report, the Singapore Government has decided to employ Nanyang University graduates and to recognise the Nanyang University degrees as equivalent to Pass Degrees of a recognised university. Selection will, as usual, be on individual merits through interview by the Public Service Commission.'

That is the stand of the Singapore Government pending the reorganisation of Nanyang University in accordance with the main principles of the Review Committee's Report. This stand on

Column: 340

Nanyang University was a stand in which at least four Members of the Barisan Sosialis who were then Parliamentary Secretaries were consulted before the statement was made. They included my ex-Parliamentary Secretary, now the Member for Serangoon Gardens, the Member for Upper Serangoon, the Member for Havelock and the Member for Nee Soon. They were then Parliamentary Secretaries.

    In fact, Sir, the Member for Nee Soon said more than once that by giving Nanyang University parity of treatment with that of the University of Malaya I would become a hero of Chinese education. At that time, the Member for Queenstown was not a Parliamentary Secretary in the P.A.P. Government; he was then an Assemblyman. We took the Assemblymen into confidence before the release of the statement, but he objected, as usual, that he was not being consulted. Everything was cut and tried and there was no use of making any contribution. I remember he was very agitated. The attitude of the Barisan Sosialis is just like that of the Member for Queenstown. If he is consulted, then it is all right - consultation has taken place with the people of Singapore. But if he is not consulted, then there has been no consultation in anything.

    Furthermore, two Members of the Barisan Sosialis, then Parliamentary Secretaries in the P.A.P. Government, were members of the very important Liaison Committee which was established, composing of Government members and members of Nanyang University, namely, the Member for Serangoon Gardens and the Member for Upper Serangoon. They had all the chance in the world to make their contributions to bring about a settlement with Nanyang University.

    Lastly, Sir, this is classic of the Barisan Sosialis: Is the Government going to reorganise Chinese schools according to the English schools as a model? In other words, will Chinese schools be anglicized; will they follow the English pattern; will they follow the colonial pattern? Sir, every country

Column: 341

has to evolve its own education system, and Singapore is no different. We intend to take the best of what is available in the four streams. In prewar days, the Government only conducted Junior Middle III Examinations for the Chinese schools and it was only in 1951 that they conducted the Senior Middle III Examinations. After a six-year secondary education, the certificate was only made equivalent to the Cambridge School Certificate which could be taken after four years in the English stream. But whatever it is, outside of Singapore, the lower secondary education system is five years starting with Form I to Form V for the English stream before they were ready for the Cambridge School Certificate Examination. In Singapore, it is quite some time now since children in English schools are able to take the Cambridge Examination in four years and not five years. So Singapore is somewhat unique in that pupils are able to take an examination in four years, whereas in the rest of the world, including the United Kingdom, they have to do it in five years. But, of course, if I do not mention the Upper Secondary education, the Barisan Sosialis will say, "There you are, secondary education only in four years." We have two years of the Higher School Certificate and it is just nice for us having to integrate the four language streams to bring about secondary education in two parts: four years for the first part and two years for the higher upper secondary section so that you do six years before you go to a University. Of course, times have changed, Sir,In the good old days, in fact, after the Senior Cambridge Examination - after nine years of education: six years in primary and three in secondary (Standards I to IX) - it was possible to do the Cambridge Examination and walk into a University. Six years primary and three years secondary, and we are at university level. But standards have been raised here as anywhere else in the world, and it is now necessary to have a 12-year education - six years primary and six

Column: 342

years secondary - before one is considered reasonably mature and adult t& join a University. So that I think it is dangerous talk indulged in by the Barisan Sosialis, and more so I am unable to forgive my former Parliamentary Secretary for talking in this strain: Is Government going to anglicize the Chinese schools and so on? At least if he could have made a suggestion on what other model he has to put forward for consideration, that would have at least been constructive. "The Singapore educational system should be this and that," but there is nothing to offer as a solution. Here, Sir, having raised this question that the Government may want to anglicize Chinese schools on the pattern of English schools in Singapore, I would like to refer to one of the files again - No. 1299/61. There is a document here 28 (C) by the Assistant Director of Education (Chinese) to the Chief Examinations Officer - School Certificate Chinese Examination:

    `Parliamentary Secretary [that is, the Member for Serangoon Gardens] has agreed to amendments to Regulations governing the award of the School Certificate (Chinese) [that is, the Secondary IV Examination) so as to bring them in line with the Cambridge [they do not like to hear the word "Cambridge" because it is English and therefore it is colonial] School Certificate standard.'

Therefore, if the Barisan Sosialis have some model or some pattern to suggest to the Government, I would like them to say so. What pattern is it that they would like the Singapore educational system to follow? And not just hide behind a facade of pretence and a silly allegation that the Government intends to do certain things.

    I am therefore deeply indebted to the Member for Anson for having proceeded with this motion, because it gave me the opportunity to listen to what was said by my former colleague - I think the Member for Farrer Park has congratulated me on my loss, which is no loss but a gain - and to answer point by point his allegations which are unfounded, malicious and dangerous, and for which he and his own Party must bear full responsibility.

Column: 343



3.28 p.m.

    Mr Chan Sun Wing (Upper Serangoon)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, having listened to the speech by the Minister for Education, I have the impression that the P.A.P. Government is very satisfied with the present state of affairs in the English and Chinese schools in Singapore. According to his speech, the people can come to this conclusion. If there are any problems in the schools in Singapore, if the teachers have any complaints and if there is any complaint about Nanyang University, they said that these are all created by the Barisan Sosialis. The Minister for Education put the blame for the mistakes and errors in the Ministry of Education on his ex-Parliamentary Secretary. Just now, the Minister for Education gave many examples. He said all these were done on the recommendation of the ex-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education. From this, if it is so, then the people can see our Minister in the past two and a half years has been useless. I feel that if it is so, he should refund the salaries which he has been drawing for the past two and a half years to the people of Singapore.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, later on I shall reply to the criticisms made by the Minister against my colleagues. Let me now express my views on this original motion. Mr Speaker, I feel that this motion is a very constructive one. The Government should not treat it as one with which the Opposition want to attack the Government, because today there are many things on policy and administration which should be reviewed since we all know that the P.A.P. when they came into office after the general elections in 1959 did not have any long-term plan. It was a result of historical developments that they came to form the Government. Under these circumstances, on complicated problems such as the education problem, any responsible Party will not boast that it has all the experience to deal with them. To the P.A.P., when they are confronted with this education problem, it is a new experience to them when they try

Column: 344

to solve it. They should admit that when performing this important task, there are bound to be mistakes. Apart from this, in the matter of policy, they have not seen eye to eye with the people. Therefore, today one Member in this Assembly has moved this motion to set up a Commission of Inquiry. This is a very good suggestion. The P.A.P. Government should remember this motion and the result of this Commission will not only benefit those who support it. It is the teachers and pupils in the schools who will derive benefit from the result of the Commission of Inquiry.

    Now let me explain why there should be such a Commission of Inquiry. At the same time, what are the terms of reference of this Commission of Inquiry? First of all, let me briefly cite some examples. For instance, in the matter of building new schools by the Government, the distribution of schools in the island in the past two years has not been satisfactory. Has it been satisfactory? Will the distribution of schools enable those who live in crowded areas go to a school which is near their residence? In building schools, does the Government take into consideration the confidence of the people who live in this island?

    As to the reunification of all streams of education, what should be the criterion? In this respect, the P.A.P. never stated clearly in its Five-Year Development Plan its education policy. They just mentioned the policy of reunification of the four streams of education without giving any concrete scheme.
